questions.question: "Tom appeared on the sidewalk with a bucket of whitewash and a long- handled brush. He surveyed the fence, and all gladness left him, and a deep melancholy settled down upon his spirit. Thirty yards of board fence nine feet high. Life to him seemed hollow, and existence but a burden. Sighing, he dipped his brush and passed it along the topmost plank: repeated the operation; did it again; compared the insignificant whitewashed streak with the far-reaching continent of un white washed fence, and sat down on a tree-box discouraged. Jim came skipping out at the gate with a tin pail, and singing Buffalo Gals. Bringing water from the town pump had always been hateful work in Tom's eyes, before, but now it did not strike him so. questions.explanation: Geneva Conventions This historic convention was signed in Geneva, Switzerland on August 12, 1949, hence it is called the Geneva Convention. Initiated by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and sponsored by the Swiss government, the purpose of this convention is to ensure the protection, security, and service of wounded and sick soldiers. Additionally, this convention recognizes the Red Cross symbol as a neutral symbol. First Geneva Convention Signed in 1864. [This convention was applicable only to wounded and sick soldiers in land warfare.] Second Geneva Convention Signed on July 6, 1906 (initiated by the ICRC). [Its purpose was to ensure the safety and security of wounded and sick soldiers in naval warfare.] During World War I (1914-1918), although numerous soldiers from the warring countries were captured the retaliatory behavior of the enemy could not be prevented through the first and second Geneva Conventions. As a result, discussions on the security of prisoners of war resumed. Third Geneva Convention Signed on July 27, 1929. [Its purpose is to ensure the security and service of prisoners of war.] However, wars did not cease, and their negative impacts continued to expand. Especially after World War II (1939-1945), countless civilians were wounded, killed, and became victims of war. In the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in Japan (August 6 and 9, 1945) alone, over three hundred thousand civilians were wounded and killed. In these cases, the previous Conventions Geneva (first, second, and third) were not effective. Therefore, discussions resumed on how to ensure the safety of civilians during wartime. Fourth Geneva Convention Signed on August 12, 1949, at another diplomatic conference in Geneva. [Its purpose is to ensure the safety of civilians during wartime.] . Additionally, this convention reviewed and consolidated the provisions and messages of the previous three conventions. As a result, all four conventions are now referred to as the 'Geneva Conventions of August 12, 1949'. Note A total of 196 countries have signed the Geneva Conventions. Even if a country signs an international agreement, it is not obligated to implement it until it is ratified by the country's government.
